TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit GridViewHeaderRowPresenter extends System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.GridViewRowPresenterBase

Docs.summary: Represents an object that is used to define the layout of a row of column headers.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewRowPresenter> object and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewHeaderRowPresenter> objects are support objects for the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridView> <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ListView.View%2A> mode that displays data in columns for a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ListView>. For more information about how to define a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridView> view, see the [GridView Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-overview.md).
You can determine when a column is moving to a new location by monitoring the <xref:System.Collections.ObjectModel.ObservableCollection%601.CollectionChanged> event that is defined for the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewColumnCollection>.
You can customize column headers in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridView> view mode by using a variety of properties that are found in this class and in related classes. For more information about these properties, and about the precedence between them, see [GridView Column Header Styles and Templates Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-column-header-styles-and-templates-overview.md).

Docs.value: if columns can be moved by the drag-and-drop operation of a column header; otherwise, . The default is .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the to use for the column headers.
Docs.value: The to use for the column header container. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you implement this class as part of a view mode, the value of this property is bound to the value of the property on the . You can customize column headers in a view mode by using a variety of properties that are found in this class and in related classes. For more information about these properties, and about the precedence between them, see [GridView Column Header Styles and Templates Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-column-header-styles-and-templates-overview.md). When you set styles, some restrictions apply. For more information, see the [Styling and Templating](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/styling-and-templating.md). ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-resources.md). *StyleResourceKey* The key that identifies the style being requested. The key refers to an existing resource in a . > [!NOTE] > Property element syntax is technically possible, but not recommended. See [Inline Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/inline-styles-and-templates.md). A binding reference using or is also possible, but uncommon. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a composite string that specifies how to format the column headers if they are displayed as strings.
Docs.value: A composite string that specifies how to format the column headers if they are displayed as strings. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the , , or property is set, this property is ignored. You can use several properties to specify the format of the column headers. If more than one property is set, the column header is formatted with the value of the property that has the highest priority. The format for a column can be set on several types. The following list shows the properties that can be used to format the column headers, ordered from lowest to highest priority: - - - ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to **true**|None|

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you implement this class as part of a view mode, the value of this property is bound to the value of the property on the . If the property and the property are both set, the takes precedence. You can customize column headers in a view mode by using a variety of properties that are found in this class and in related classes. For more information about these properties, and about the precedence between them, see [GridView Column Header Styles and Templates Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-column-header-styles-and-templates-overview.md). ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-resources.md). *TemplateResourceKey* The key that identifies the template being requested. The key refers to an existing resource in a . > [!NOTE] > Property element syntax is technically possible, but not recommended. See [Inline Styles and Templates](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/inline-styles-and-templates.md). A binding reference using or is also possible, but uncommon.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a that provides logic that selects the data template to use to display a column header.
Docs.value: The that chooses the to use to display each column header. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the property and the property are both set, the takes precedence. When you implement this class as part of a view mode, the value of this property is bound to the value of the property on the . You can customize column headers in a view mode by using a variety of properties that are found in this class and in related classes. For more information about these properties, and about the precedence between them, see [GridView Column Header Styles and Templates Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-column-header-styles-and-templates-overview.md). ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Values *MyDataTemplateSelectorImplementation* A class derived from that implements a practical override. For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-namespaces-and-namespace-mapping-for-wpf-xaml.md). *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-resources.md). *DataTemplateSelectorClassKey* The key that identifies the selector implementation being requested. The key refers to a derived class that implements a practical override. For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/xaml-namespaces-and-namespace-mapping-for-wpf-xaml.md). You can also programmatically add an instance of your class as a resource to a resource dictionary.

Docs.value: An object that represents the content of a tooltip for the column headers.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you implement this class as part of a view mode, the value of this property is bound to the value of the property on the . You can customize column headers in a view mode by using a variety of properties that are found in this class and in related classes. For more information about these properties, and about the precedence between them, see [GridView Column Header Styles and Templates Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/controls/gridview-column-header-styles-and-templates-overview.md). ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ``` - or - ``` ## XAML Values `toolTipContent` A string that becomes the display text for the . `toolTipObjectContent` An object to use as the content for the tooltip. Typically, this object is a or some other element that defines a layout for the , such as a text element. In this usage, a element is implicitly created from the parsed [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)], and the `toolTipObjectContent` content is set as its property. <`ToolTip` .../> See . ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnLostMouseCapture(class System.Windows.Input.MouseEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the event for the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.LostMouseCapture> event occurs while a column is moving to a new position, the move is canceled.
This implementation does not handle the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.LostMouseCapture> event.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnMouseLeftButtonDown(class System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the event that occurs when the user presses the left mouse button inside a .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewHeaderRowPresenter.AllowsColumnReorder%2A> is `true`, this method prepares a column to be dragged to another location in the column header row.
This implementation handles the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeftButtonDown> event by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> event argument to `true`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnMouseLeftButtonUp(class System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the event that occurs when the user releases the left mouse button.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewHeaderRowPresenter.AllowsColumnReorder%2A> is `true`, and if the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeftButtonUp> event occurs after a column is dragged to a new location, the column is moved.
This implementation handles the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeftButtonUp> event by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> event argument to `true`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnMouseMove(class System.Windows.Input.MouseEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the event that occurs when the user moves the mouse.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewHeaderRowPresenter.AllowsColumnReorder%2A> property is set to `true` and the user presses the left mouse button, this method implements the visual behavior that occurs when the user drags a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.GridViewColumnHeader> to a new location. This method override sets the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> event argument to `true` for the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.MouseMove> event even if the user does not press the left mouse button.
